Received a balance bill from an out-of-network ER provider? Learn how the No Surprises Act protects you from surprise emergency room billing.

Balance Billing After ER Visit: How to Use No Surprises Act to Fight Surprise Bills

Understanding Your Situation

You had a medical emergency and went to the nearest hospital emergency room. You did everything right — you used your insurance, provided your card, and received emergency care. Weeks later, you receive a bill from the ER physician, radiologist, or other provider stating they're out-of-network and demanding payment for the 'balance' — the difference between their charge and what your insurance paid. This is surprise balance billing, and since January 2022, it is illegal under the federal No Surprises Act. If you received emergency services on or after January 1, 2022, you are protected and should only owe your in-network cost-sharing amount.

Why This Happens

Emergency room balance billing occurs because:

ER Physicians Often Contract Separately: Many emergency room doctors are not direct hospital employees — they're independent contractors or work for staffing agencies. These groups may be out-of-network with your insurance even though the hospital is in-network.

No Patient Choice in Emergency: In a medical emergency, you can't choose your ER provider. You go to the nearest hospital and receive care from whoever is on duty.

Pre-2022 Balance Billing Was Legal: Before the No Surprises Act, out-of-network ER providers could legally balance bill patients for the difference between their charges and insurance payments — sometimes $10,000+.

Billing Departments May Not Know the Law: Some providers continue sending surprise bills out of habit or ignorance of the No Surprises Act requirements.

Out-of-Network Radiology, Labs, and Ancillary Services: Even if your ER doctor is in-network, radiologists, pathologists, or lab providers may be out-of-network and attempt balance billing.

What To Check

Verify your protections and gather documentation:

✓ Date of service: Was your ER visit on or after January 1, 2022? If yes, No Surprises Act applies
✓ Type of service: Was it emergency care? (Includes stabilizing treatment for emergency medical conditions)
✓ Provider type: Is the balance bill from an ER physician, radiologist, anesthesiologist, or other ancillary provider?
✓ Notice and consent: Did you sign a written consent form agreeing to out-of-network charges? (This should NOT exist for emergency services — waivers are prohibited for emergencies)
✓ EOB review: Check your insurance EOB to see what they paid and what patient responsibility they calculated
✓ Bill amount: Is the provider billing you for the balance after insurance or the full amount?

What To Do Next

Step 1: Invoke No Surprises Act Protections
Send a dispute letter immediately stating:
• 'This balance bill violates the No Surprises Act (Public Law 116-260)'
• 'I received emergency services at [Hospital Name] on [Date]'
• 'Under federal law, I am only responsible for in-network cost-sharing amounts'
• 'I did not and could not provide informed consent to waive surprise billing protections for emergency services'
• 'I demand withdrawal of this improper balance bill and correction of any credit bureau reports'

Step 2: Use Our Dispute Tool
Generate a professional, law-compliant dispute letter automatically with our Out-of-Network Billing Dispute tool.

Step 3: Report the Violation to Federal Authorities
File a complaint with:
• No Surprises Help Desk: Call 1-800-985-3059
• CMS Online: CMS No Surprises Portal
• State Insurance Commissioner: File a complaint with your state regulator

Step 4: Contact Your Insurance Company
Call your insurer and explain you received a surprise balance bill in violation of the No Surprises Act. Request they:
• Confirm the provider is out-of-network
• Verify you only owe in-network cost-sharing
• Contact the provider to resolve the billing issue

Step 5: Do Not Pay the Balance Bill
Do not pay the improper balance while disputing. Payment may be interpreted as acceptance. Keep all correspondence and send disputes via certified mail for proof of delivery.

Step 6: Dispute Any Credit Report Entries
If the provider reports the balance bill to credit bureaus, dispute it immediately citing the No Surprises Act violation. Medical debts from illegal balance bills should be removed from credit reports.

Frequently Asked Questions

What qualifies as an emergency under the No Surprises Act?

An 'emergency medical condition' is defined as a condition with symptoms severe enough that a prudent layperson would reasonably expect that absence of immediate medical attention could result in serious jeopardy to health, serious impairment of bodily functions, or serious dysfunction of any bodily organ. This includes chest pain, severe injuries, stroke symptoms, difficulty breathing, and many other acute conditions. If you reasonably believed you had an emergency, you're likely protected.

Can I be balance billed if I went to an out-of-network hospital?

If you received emergency services, No Surprises Act protections apply regardless of the hospital's network status. You can only be charged in-network cost-sharing amounts even if the entire facility is out-of-network. For non-emergency services at out-of-network facilities, different rules apply.

What if the provider says I signed a consent form?

Consent forms that waive No Surprises Act protections are prohibited for emergency services. You cannot waive your rights for emergency care, even if you signed something. For non-emergency services, waivers must meet strict federal requirements (72-hour notice, plain language, good faith estimate, etc.). Review any forms carefully and dispute if requirements weren't met.

What if my ER visit was in 2021 or earlier?

The No Surprises Act took effect January 1, 2022. For earlier dates, check if your state had surprise billing protections (many did). Some states like New York, California, Florida, and Texas had laws prohibiting balance billing for emergency services before the federal law. Contact your state insurance commissioner for guidance.

How long does it take to resolve a No Surprises Act dispute?

Resolution timelines vary. Some providers withdraw improper bills quickly once they realize the legal violation. Others may require federal intervention. If the dispute goes to Independent Dispute Resolution (IDR), it can take 30-90 days. Keep detailed records and follow up regularly with the provider, your insurer, and federal regulators.
